en_first_half: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and brought the coast down, madly. The air among the
en_second_half: houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever, sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.

es_first_half: Terminado el almuerzo, el señor Lorry salió a dar un paseíto por la playa. No se divisaba desde ella la pequeña e irregular ciudad de Dover, excepción hecha de sus tejados que, metidos entre picachos de canteras calizas, semejaban gigantesca ostra marina. Era la playa un desierto erizado de peñascales y plagado de escollos, donde la mar hacía lo que se la antojaba, y lo que se la antojaba invariablemente era destruir. Casi de continuo rugía contra la ciudad, bramaba contra los farallones, embestía contra los peñascos que pretendían oponerse a su paso y los derribaba con estruendo. Respirábase en las casas un olor tan fuerte a pescado, que no parecía sino que los
es_second_half: habitantes de las aguas salían de éstas para curar en las casas sus enfermedades, de la misma manera que las personas enfermas suelen buscar la salud en los baños de mar. Algunos, muy pocos, se dedicaban a la pesca en aquellas aguas, y si durante el día la playa estaba siempre desierta, en cambio por la noche se veían personas que clavaban sus miradas inquietas en la inmensidad del mar. Comerciantes insignificantes a los que nunca se veía hacer un negocio, realizaban de pronto fortunas inmensas que no tenían explicación racional, y era muy de notar que nadie, por aquellos lugares, podía sufrir la presencia de una luz, de la que huían como del demonio.

en_results_raw: <output>Madame Defarge's aspect was so established and severe, that it was startling to see her, as she sat at her knitting in an upper room of the wine-shop one evening shortly afterwards, laying aside her work to bend over a great wooden frame, stooping down to keep some cinders together, and blowing them into a little flame. The frame stood in a recess by the window, exclusive of the shop, and retired from it. That it was used as a casement for some purpose, was evident, though not so clear what the purpose was. Three dull nights in succession, as the lamp just above the frame guttered and flared, Madame Defarge, having drawn her chair beside it, and heaped fresh fuel on the fire, sat there watching. She worked at her knitting always. The steady regular click of the needles was audible in the lull of the night. But, her eyes never left the frame, save to glance at it and knit again.

"It is a good thing," said Madame Defarge, knitting steadily, "and it will do a vast amount of good." "It is equally a bad thing," returned the man, "and it will produce a vast amount of misery." "Hush!" said Madame Defarge, raising her finger. "Hear the people singing." The man looked about him, and there was a great roar of voices in the distance, as if a whole sea were in song. "It is they who sing," said Madame Defarge, composedly, "while we knit." "And why do they sing?" asked the man, with a searching look at her. "Because they are happy." "And why are they happy?" "Because they are free." "And what is that, Madame Defarge, if it is not a dream of blood and death?" "It is their freedom from a system that has oppressed and ground them into the earth," said Madame Defarge, lifting her eyes from her work for the first time. "It is their freedom from a regime that has denied them bread, dignity, and life. The Guillotine is their retribution, their justice. It is the only way to balance the scales that have been so cruelly tipped against them. It is not merely an instrument of death; it is a symbol of liberation. It is the dawn of a new era, where the people will rise and claim what is rightfully theirs. It is the voice of the oppressed, the roar of the dispossessed, the justice of the common man. It is the end of tyranny and the beginning of equality. So, tell me again, monsieur, are you satisfied?"

"What do they intend to do with me?" he whispered, his voice barely audible, betraying a deep-seated fear that had been suppressed for far too long. The question hung in the air, heavy and fraught with the tension of uncertainty. Defarge, with a slight nod, indicated that he was about to find out. The man's hands, which had been clenched into fists, began to tremble, betraying his inner turmoil. He looked around the gathering, his eyes searching for any sign of hope or reassurance, but found none. The room, filled with the hum of whispered conversations and the clinking of glasses, seemed to close in on him, isolating him in his despair. "Tell me," he implored, his voice cracking, "what fate awaits me?" The question was not just directed at Defarge but at the universe itself, a desperate plea for clarity in a world that had shown him nothing but cruelty and injustice. Defarge, understanding the gravity of the moment, prepared himself to deliver the news, knowing that his words would shape the man's destiny.

The struggle is palpable, a constant tug-of-war between the allure of immediate gains and the long-term consequences of compromising values. This internal battle is further complicated by external pressures, such as market demands, competition, and regulatory requirements. Business owners and leaders often find themselves at a crossroads, where every decision could either reinforce their company's reputation or tarnish it. The pressure to succeed can be immense, leading some to prioritize short-term gains over the sustainable growth that comes from ethical practices. Yet, those who manage to balance these competing interests often find a way to not only thrive but also to lead their industries with integrity. The conflict, therefore, is not just about making money but about defining what success truly means in the context of business. It's about deciding whether success is measured by quarterly profits or by the legacy left behind, the impact on employees, customers, and the community. This ongoing conflict is a testament to the complexity of the business world, where the right choice is not always the easy one, and where the true test of leadership lies in navigating these moral dilemmas with wisdom and courage.

La guerra había transformado a su natal tierra en un lugar desconocido, lleno de odio y violencia. La promesa de unirse a su familia y a empezar una vida nueva parecía cada vez más un sueño lejano. La incertidumbre y el temor se apoderaban de él, recordándole las palabras de Sydney Carton antes de su sacrificio: "Voy a morir en tu lugar". Esa promesa, tan desesperada pero tan noble, seguía resonando en su mente, llenándola de gratitud y de pesar. Darnay sabía que debía enfrentar lo que vino, pero el mero pensamiento de volver a Francia lo llenaba de una mezcla de ansiedad y determinación. La decisión de regresar había sido difícil, pero ahora, con cada paso que acercaba a su destino, se hacía más clara. Había que enfrentar el pasado para construir un futuro.

The Doctor's mind was stored with a knowledge of his time, and his hand was skilful in its touch; he was a man of such humane and gentle presence that even the most distracted would grow calm in his company, and the most hardened might feel a flicker of remorse. His practice was not confined to the poor, for his worth was acknowledged by all classes, and he treated each patient with the same care and respect, regardless of their station in life. The Doctor's clinic became a sanctuary for the sick and the suffering, a place where the whispers of hope could be heard amidst the clamor of pain and despair. His work was not just in the treatment of physical ailments but in the healing of the soul, for he understood that true health encompassed both body and mind. As the days passed, Doctor Manette's clinic grew in renown, attracting those who sought not only medical aid but also solace and understanding. His ability to listen, to truly hear the stories of his patients, set him apart as a healer of the highest order. The village of Beauvais was asleep, and Monsieur Gabelle, though for the moment a person of some authority and dignity, as being in the King's employ, knew that the village could awake easily to a new order of things, and in which of its sleepers a great functionary might be resolved to nothing by to-morrow's sun. He had his misgivings, therefore, and they showed themselves in a sweat that made his fancy warmer and more oppressive as the night grew darker and colder, and the horses splashed and plunged thicker and thicker. The village of Beauvais being at length left behind, and the horses having picked their careful way through the last of the writhing morass that wrestled with the wheels, and through the faint mists that tried to contend with the light of the December morning as it tried to force its way up the sky, the traveller and his equipage came into a region of stone walls and bare trees, where the mills were motionless, the threshing-floors deserted, the wells unvisited, and the few dwelling-houses only made known to one another's sombre fronts by the little patches of miserable grass that were stunted between them and the road. The village of Beauvais, with its stone cathedral and its jail, seemed very distant; the murky street that wound its way up into the main street of the little town, and the mire in that street which had so bespattered the horses' legs, appeared at a great distance; the village forge, where the blacksmith fire had been quenched last night, and the wheel of Monsieur Gabelle's post-chaise had been chipped by a flint in the mud, seemed as far off as if it had been in a foreign country. The few people who were about--poor women, carrying bundles home from the market, or men and women coming from the country to the market, with poultry and small stock of garden produce--passed along the road, keeping as much out of the way as possible, and glancing at Monsieur the Postmaster with a marked look of distrust and dislike. The universal watchfulness against spies, and the universal disposition to mistrust every stranger, communicated a queer sensation to Monsieur Gabelle's heart. The sensation was, that the eyes which were directed towards him seemed to go through him, and were not to be satisfied until they had seen him through. Thus, Monsieur Gabelle, picking his way with as good a grace as he could under the circumstances, and occasionally saying, "Good day!" to these suspicious stares, which were never returned, or at most were answered with a nod, or one word, "There!" at length splashed his way out of the village that was in a kind of secret ferment, and came into the open high-road. Here, the stone walls on either side closed in the vista like a deep lane, arched over by a gloomy sky that seemed too near the ground, and in which there seemed a heavy gloom as if to the very earth. The horses moved with a restricted clatter, for the road was rough with jagged stone, and the wheels rattled and bumped at a poor pace. The village was soon left far behind; and the gloomy stone walls, with their overhanging arch of troubles, seemed to make the way lonelier and more secluded. Monsieur Gabelle, musing as he rode, was conscious of a sick apprehension at the heart that this ride would end badly for him. The Postmaster had heard whispers of the growing discontent among the people, and he knew that his position as a functionary of the King made him a target for their anger. The cold air seemed to freeze his thoughts, making him more anxious with each passing moment. He wondered if he should reach his destination safely, or if the revolution brewing would erupt before he could escape its grasp. The landscape around him was bleak and unforgiving, mirroring the mood of the country. As the sun rose higher, casting a dim light over the desolate scene, Monsieur Gabelle felt a growing sense of isolation and fear. The distant sound of a horse galloping towards him broke the oppressive silence, and his heart skipped a beat. Was it a messenger from the Farmer-General, or was it a harbinger of the chaos to come? He urged his horses to move faster, his mind racing with possibilities, as the approaching rider drew closer. The tension in the air was palpable, and Monsieur Gabelle knew that the next few moments could determine his fate.

Each season brings its own unique beauty and challenges, shaping the lives of those who experience them. From the vibrant greens and blooming flowers of spring, to the golden hues and crisp air of autumn, the cycle of seasons is a testament to Earth's dynamic nature. Winter, with its cold and often snowy landscapes, demands adaptation and resilience. People around the globe have developed various traditions and customs to celebrate or cope with the changing seasons. In some cultures, winter is a time for hibernation and reflection, while others see it as a period of festivity and joy. The agricultural calendar has long been dictated by the seasons, influencing when crops are planted and harvested. Today, even in our modern, technology-driven world, the seasons continue to play a significant role in our lives, affecting our moods, activities, and even our health. The transition from one season to another is marked by changes not only in temperature and weather but also in the natural world around us. Animals migrate, plants go dormant, and humans adjust their routines. The cycle of seasons is a constant reminder of the planet's vitality and our interconnectedness with nature. As we navigate through the cold months of winter, we are reminded of the promise of spring's renewal and the inevitable return of summer's warmth. This perpetual cycle is a fundamental aspect of life on Earth, influencing cultures, economies, and ecosystems in profound ways.

en_results_raw: storm. The atmosphere in the office was thick with tension and the smell of ink and old parchment. Sydney, despite his fatigue, felt a sense of urgency that kept him going. The looming storm outside only added to the pressure, as if nature itself was conspiring to hurry along the completion of his task. With each document sorted, filed, or discarded, Sydney felt a small victory. Yet, the pile seemed endless, and the hours stretched on, each minute feeling like an eternity. His eyes grew heavy, betraying his exhaustion, but the thought of Mr. Stryver’s disappointment or worse, his anger, was enough to keep Sydney pushing through the weariness. The clock ticked relentlessly, marking the passage of time, as Sydney worked with a diligence that bordered on desperation. He knew that once the storm hit, the office would be inaccessible for days, and this was his last chance to complete the monumental task set before him. The rain began to tap against the window panes, a soft prelude to the tempest that was soon to break. Sydney’s focus sharpened, his movements precise and swift. He was determined to finish, no matter how long it took. The night was his adversary, and he would not let it win. As the first flashes of lightning illuminated the room, casting eerie shadows, Sydney finally allowed himself a brief moment of respite, looking out at the storm that mirrored the turmoil within him. But then, with renewed vigor, he returned to his work, driven by a singular purpose. The night was still young, and there was much to do.

Su mente trabajaba a toda velocidad, analizando información y posibles conexiones. A pesar de su aparente indiferencia, estaba completamente comprometido con su misión. Sabía que cualquier descuido podría ser fatal. Continuó su vigilancia, esperando el momento oportuno para actuar. La tensión aumentó cuando una mujer en la esquina del café se levantó repentinamente, dejando caer accidentalmente un sobre sobre el piso. El espía, aprovechando el desorden, se apoderó del sobre mientras el resto de los clientes se distraía. Al abrirlo, encontró un mapa con rutas marcadas y datos codificados. Era el peldaño clave que necesitaba. Con una sonrisa satisfecha, el espía se sentó de nuevo, planeando su próximo movimiento. La misión estaba en camino a ser completada.

Yet, the very stones of Paris, then, seemed thirsty for blood, as though they had been bruised and broken by the iron-shod hoofs of the cavalry that had charged upon them repeatedly; and as though, in the fancy of the beholder, they retained a dreadful recollection of the crimson streams so freely poured upon them. There was much coming and going; the posts were numerous; great heaps of correspondence passed between the police authorities and the provinces; the officers of the King were for ever in the saddle, and for ever in the bosom of the people; there was much whispering and little speaking; and a restless and uneasy feeling pervaded the atmosphere of Paris, which did not fail to strike the senses of the time-worn prisoner in his dungeon.

And as Madame Defarge disappeared into the shadows, the people remained, their eyes fixed on the horizon, waiting for the dawn of change.

es_results_raw: Lucía despertó con una sensación extraña. El silencio de la casa era opresivo, y el frío nocturno envolvía su habitación con un abrazo inmovilizador. Se sentó en la cama, intentando recordar los sueños que habían visitado su mente, pero nada se hacía presente con claridad. La oscuridad parecía más densa que nunca, y el eco de su respiración resonaba en las paredes. Decidió encender una lámpara tenue, buscando aliviar la tensión que comenzaba a crecer en su pecho. La noche había sido larga y tormentosa, llenada de pensamientos que habían evitado encontrar su paz en el sueño. Con la luz débil iluminando su rostro, Lucía se preguntó qué extrañas circunstancias le esperaban en este día nuevo. La incertidumbre la envolvió, y aunque sabía que debía enfrentar lo que vino, no podía evitar sentir un temor palpable. Despertar tan temprano, con el mundo aún en su más profundo silencio, le brindaba un momento de reflexión forzada. Lo que había pasado la noche anterior, las palabras intercambiadas antes de dormirse, todo se mezclaba en un caos de emociones. Con una respiración lenta, Lucía se levantó, decidida a enfrentar el día que se avecinaba, sin importar lo que pudiera traer consigo.

en_second_half: his knees and his head in his hands, that he was in some misty way asking himself, “Why not?” The sagacity of the man of business perceived an advantage here, and determined to hold it.
en_results: the table, that his eyes were not on the fire, but on a corner of the room where the shadows gathered deep, and where the wall itself seemed to be contracted into a more retired and gloomy
en_results_raw: the table, that his eyes were not on the fire, but on a corner of the room where the shadows gathered deep, and where the wall itself seemed to be contracted into a more retired and gloomy nook. The obscurity of that corner, the old wine-stains upon the wall, the litter of shoes and other detritus of a day's occupation, grouped together there in the dark like ghosts of old pleasures and old business, all became, in Mr. Lorry's fancy, expressive of secret intelligence and foreknowledge. He could not have said why he thought, or whether he thought rightly or not, but the sensation was so strong upon him that he put out his hand to the small candelabrum on the table, and called to Jerry, who was standing buttoning his greatcoat at the door, "A candle, Jerry!" When the light shone in the corner, it did but throw the shadow of a wooden archway and the corner cupboard heavier, and show the cobwebs to advantage. Mr. Lorry, stooping to look into the corner, felt his hair stir upon his head, straightened himself, and said, "Jerry, what is back of that cupboard?" "Only dust, sir, I hope," said Jerry, with a curious glance at his master. "Nothing else?" "Nothing else, sir." "It is bartered and sold. Hush! Don't speak of it!" Mr. Lorry whispered this, as if he had suddenly remembered that they were not alone. He looked round at the closed door, and, seeming to assure himself that no one was listening, whispered again, "It is a paper from the Doctor, Jerry. A most particular and important paper, that I received from him myself. It is to be delivered to no one—certainly not to the bearer of these letters—till I so direct. It is to be kept in this place of safety, till I give the word. Take it, and remember!" With a grave shake of the head, Mr. Lorry took from the corner a small, very old, and dirty ragged bag and put it in his pocket. He then signed to Jerry to come nearer, and, bending down, impressed upon him in a low voice the necessity of rigorous fidelity and silence concerning the matter. Jerry, much astonished and not a little disturbed in his mind by the mystery, promised to keep it secret, took the candlestick, and retired, closing the door carefully after him. Mr. Lorry, left alone, looked steadily at the corner until the candle in his hand burnt down in his hand and went out. Then, he sat there, in the dark, until the day began to break.

He reproached himself for his weakness in yielding to such fatigue, and hastily preparing, he went straight to Tellson's Bank. The city was astir, and the streets were echoing with the hum of a busy day. He quickened his pace, his mind preoccupied with the weight of the secrets he carried and the uncertainty of the outcome. As he entered the bank, he was greeted by the usual nods and murmurs of his fellow clerks, none of whom knew of the clandestine mission he had undertaken. He made his way to his desk, determined to focus on his work and push aside the consuming thoughts of Doctor Alexandre Manette and his daughter, Lucie.

A little tuft of coarse grass and weeds struggled with the stones for existence in one corner; a few grains of barley lay there too, and some straw, and half-a-dozen idle sparrows came fearlessly in and out at the door, which was open. A very small candle in a bottle, such as is usual in the country, was burning on the table, and a chair and a wooden settle were the only seats. A stone bottle too, properly belonging to the little shop — if it merited the name of a shop — stood on a shelf of rough deal; a stone mug, with a broken lip, was soaking beside it; an old knife and fork were in it; and an almost empty ragged cloth sack, with holes in it, hung over the back of the settle. On the hob, three-legged and black, a kettle was steaming and boiling to supply a meagre meal with tea. Such was the interior of the wine-shop, which might be likened to the kernel of some not very large or sound fruit; not suggesting a prosperous ripe apple, for instance, but rather a meagre plum that would disappoint the teeth.

en_results_raw: “Fashion of speech again!” But, Mr. Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to me, as you represent it to be. The shadows of the past are long, and they cling to one with a stubbornness that is hard to shake. I have lived through times that have scarred my mind and soul, and the memories of those times are not so easily banished. Your life, though entwined with mine through unfortunate circumstances, has not been as burdened by the weight of history. You speak of starting anew, of leaving the past behind, but for me, the past is a relentless companion. It whispers in my ear when I am alone, it haunts my dreams, and it casts a long shadow over my days. I envy your ability to look forward with such optimism, but I am bound by the chains of my experiences. Oblivion is a luxury I cannot afford, a distant shore I may never reach. My mind is a gallery of horrors and injustices, and while I strive to move beyond them, they persist in defining me. Therefore, Mr. Darnay, do not be surprised if I am slow to forget, for the ghosts of my past are not so easily laid to rest.

"My good man," Stryver began, regaining his composure, "I meant no disrespect to your nationality. "Soy Carlos St. Evrémonde, descendiente de una noble familia francesa, aquí por mis propios motivos." La tensión en el salón se intensificó con su afirmación, mientras los ojos de los presentes se intercambiaban miradas sorprendidas y escépticas. Darnay, consciente de la incredulidad que sus palabras despertaban, decidió explicar su situación más a fondo, buscando desmistificar cualquier malentendido. "He venido a Inglaterra para investigar la herencia de un tío distante, y mi llegada fue por voluntad propia", continuó, intentando mantener la calma ante la obvía desconfianza. La reacción de los presentes varió, desde el desdén hasta la curiosidad, pero era evidente que su afirmación de no ser prisionero había introducido una nueva dinámica en la sala. Darnay sabía que tendría que ser muy cuidadoso con sus palabras y acciones, pues el entorno era claro y peligroso, y cualquier malentendido podría tener consecuencias graves para él.

en_first_half: This was the Carmagnole. As it passed, leaving Lucie frightened and bewildered in the doorway of the wood-sawyer’s
en_second_half: house, the feathery snow fell as quietly and lay as white and soft, as if it had never been.
en_results: shop, it struck her that the fierce and threatening looks directed towards her were not personal,
en_results_raw: shop, it struck her that the fierce and threatening looks directed towards her were not personal, but the result of the general excitement. The men danced, leaped, and sung; the women, with their arms entwined, and their long hair streaming, bounded in the circles that were formed about the fiercest dancers, whose unshod feet were as active as their eyes were fierce. The Carmagnole swept on through the narrow street, and died away at the bottom of it, where the houses were larger and the distance between them greater. Lucie, hastening down the street to regain her own home, was stopped by a man whom she recognized as Defarge, the wine-shop keeper. He looked at her for a moment, as if he were sorry for her alarm, and then took her by the hand, saying, “Come with me, my Gaspard’s daughter.” Lucie, reassured by his gentle voice and touch, accompanied him. They turned from the street through a grated door which she had often seen, but never noticed particularly before. It opened by a key, and shut again with a click, when they were within a high-walled enclosure. In the centre was a large paved yard, in which stood a fountain, playing. The few people in it took no notice of them as they passed towards a large house, the door of which also was opened by a key, and shut with a click. Defarge led her up a steep staircase into a large, sunny room, where a woman sat knitting. The woman looked up, and her face too was one of gentle welcome. “Welcome, welcome, my dear!” she said, rising. “You are safe here, you are quite safe. Do not be frightened. You are among friends.” Lucie, greatly relieved, thanked them and sat down, trying to regain her composure. The woman returned to her knitting, and Defarge explained that they had brought her there for her safety, as the streets were unsafe during such times of unrest. He assured her that she would be protected and that they would help her find her father if possible. Lucie felt a deep sense of gratitude and trust towards these strangers who had shown her such kindness. As she settled into the room, she couldn’t help but wonder about the mysterious references to her father and the unsettling atmosphere outside. The day’s events had left her with more questions than answers, but for now, she was safe and that was a comfort.

The snowflakes danced around him, and the wind howled, yet he remained motionless, as if he had been petrified by the weight of his memories. Lucie, with her child in her arms, approached cautiously, her heart heavy with concern. "Father?" she called softly, her voice barely audible over the storm's fury. There was no response, only the sound of the wind and the soft patter of snow. She stepped closer, her eyes filled with tears, and gently touched his shoulder. "Father, it's Lucie," she whispered, her voice trembling. Slowly, ever so slowly, Doctor Manette's gaze shifted towards her, as if he was emerging from a deep trance. The light from the lamp flickered, casting shadows that danced across his face, revealing the torment and the struggle within. "My dear," he finally spoke, his voice a mere whisper, "the past... it never truly leaves us, does it?" Lucie, with a mixture of fear and compassion, embraced her father, holding him tightly as if to shield him from the ghosts of his past. "No, Father, it doesn't," she replied, her voice filled with empathy. "But you are not alone. We are here with you, always." The storm raged on outside, but within the warmth of the house, a different kind of battle was fought—a battle for healing and hope. As they stood there, the snow continued to fall, blanketing the world outside in a pristine white, while inside, the Manette family began another day of facing their past, together.

en_first_half: Frantic acclamations were again raised. Doctor Manette sat down, with his eyes looking around, and his lips trembling; his daughter drew
en_second_half: closer to him. The craving man on the jury rubbed his hands together, and restored the usual hand to his mouth.
en_results: the veil over her golden hair, and put her hand in his. The crowd, restrained for a moment, broke its bounds, and
en_results_raw: the veil over her golden hair, and put her hand in his. The crowd, restrained for a moment, broke its bounds, and rushed upon the two. The Defarges, with their hands upon their breasts, and in every attitude of living deference and submission, were the only people in the tumbril who did not spring up. The Vengeance was the first to leap to her feet, embracing Madame Defarge, and kissing her cheek. "Long live the Republic One and Indivisible, and Death to its Enemies!" was the cry. It arose among the people with the sound of a sea breaking and roaring up to fitful gusts of wind along the beach-head of the tremendous Revolution. It was taken up by a thousand voices; passed from rank to rank of the populace; seemed to be echoed and re-echoed by all the neighbouring buildings; and was lost at last, as the last flock of birds in the sky is lost to the eye, in the tumult of the distance. The vehicle moved on. The Doctor's arm was tightly clasped by Lucie, who no longer veiled her golden hair, but who had put it back, and was supporting her father, looking steadfastly before her. The Defarges had a quiet talk together in a corner, and several times exchanged a mysterious glance with Madame Defarge, who looked steadily at the Doctor as if she could have torn his heart out when he looked towards her. The Vengeance was very agreeable, and not too rough of speech; offering to take Lucie's bonnet and shawl, and assuring them that the ladies in the crowd were the gentlest and mercifullest of women; that, on the contrary, they were the ministers of mercy and justice, who would immolate themselves to the last drop of their blood for "The Republic One and Indivisible." The Doctor's mind was so confused that he scarcely heard her, and only saw in his distress the faces of those among whom he was to be carried at the imminent peril of his life. The sun had gone down; it was deep shadows and crimson lights; the distant roar of the city hummed like a sea; the Defarges and the Vengeance talked low to Madame Defarge; the faces in the crowd were cruel and sneering; all the knives and swords in Paris seemed to be flashing in the sun as the people danced and leaped, and the life of one poor man hung by a breath. The cart lumbered on, and the jolting of the wheels over the uneven stones of the streets communicated itself to the Doctor's frame, which it shook as if it were palsied. Lucie's hold of his arm never relaxed; but, she was so distressed that she turned her face, wet with tears, for a moment on her father's breast, and whispered, "O my dear, good father!"

en_first_half: “You had great influence but yesterday, Doctor Manette; let it at least be tried. These judges, and all
en_second_half: the men in power, are very friendly to you, and very recognisant of your services; are they not?”
en_results: the functionaries and attendants here assembled, though paid by and therefore at the beck and call
en_results_raw: the functionaries and attendants here assembled, though paid by and therefore at the beck and call of the Power that calls itself the Republic, have not, I entreat you to believe, imbibed its spirit. They are not insensible to the agony of others, and they are not blind to the plain facts before them. The very air of this place, charged with the wretchedness of its inmates, speaks against the cruelty of condemning an innocent man. Let us appeal to their humanity, to their sense of justice, and to their own self-interest in maintaining the integrity of their proceedings. They have seen the evidence, they have heard the testimonies, and yet they hesitate. This hesitation is our opportunity. Let us not waste it by yielding to despair. Present our case with clarity and conviction. Remind them of the weight of their responsibility and the irreversible nature of their decision. Let us argue for leniency, for a retrial, for any chance that might save an innocent life. Remember, Doctor Manette, your reputation, your very life, was once reclaimed from the jaws of oblivion. It is not too late for hope.”

You shall leave England tomorrow. I will take your place. I am in all respects so like you, that I can become you, and I will become you. You shall remain secret, and apart, until all danger is over. Then you shall be free to go where you please. Do you understand me?’” The prisoner, with his hands before his face, replied in a low voice, “‘I understand.’” “‘It is better for both. You shall be saved from this, and I- I have no hope of salvation. It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.’” Carton’s hand was now on the prisoner’s shoulder, and his voice was full of a solemnity which gave it an awful force. “‘I am thankful that I can do it. Go, and think of me. You shall be recompensed. I ask nothing for myself in this world.’” The prisoner, with tears streaming down his face, looked up at Carton and murmured, “‘God bless you!’” Carton smiled, and waved his hand, and the prisoner was gone.
